text:
Hi everyone & <@U03GEHQPL0G>, I wanted to give you all a little heads up on a possible eng pivot we’re experimenting with internally. We’ve been testing out whether we could provide the same user experience without the to-spec DLC library, but rather using PSBTs under the hood. We want to see if we can hit the same security aspects, with self-custodial locking bitcoin and having pre-defined outcomes.

The benefit, if this could work and our customers felt it was equally good, would mean we would need much less or no customization on the bitcoin wallets.

Just wanted to provide that heads up! Not sure where we’ll land on this yet but we’ll keep your team up to date! Let me know if you have any questions

text: Thanks for the heads up! This makes sense given the additional complexities with the DLC library. Could PSBTs essentially execute DLCs though? I would have presumed that wasn't possible.

text:
Correct, they could not sign a DLC that was built to the official spec, which uses Adapter Signature signing technology, which is different from Schnorr.

But we are finding that nearly all the security benefits of the DLC, but less-so the privacy ones, can be provided with schnorr multisigs, PSBTs for the predefined outcomes, and the threshold of oracles/attestors (which is part of the DLC spec as well).

text: DLCs are basically a trustless contract between two parties relying on a set of oracles, with lots of privacy. This new system has the same without the privacy benefits, but those can be provided with a clever BTC wallet that doesn’t use addresses, for example.

text: What we have done so far getting DLCs / Adaptor Sigs into Leather has been awesome, but we got quite blocked on the hardware wallet side, and we found many of our larger potential customers, like institutions, require hardware signing. For example, getting Adaptor sig signing into Ledger was a huge project and blocker
